block.p: Re ''Altered Salmon Leading Way to Dinner Plates, but Rules Lag'' (front page, May 1):
Re ''Altered Salmon Leading Way to Dinner Plates, but Rules Lag'' (front page, May 1):

Skeptics are right to question the Food and Drug Administration's ability to insure that genetically engineered fish will not harm the environment. Their cavalier attitude seems reckless given the rapid development of this radical new technology.

It might be reassuring to some if the Environmental Protection Agency stepped in, but that agency's lax regulation of biotechnology is also worrisome. The agency does not perform environmental impact assessments, leaving it to biotech companies to assure that their products won't cause harm.
Agencies that should be acting in the public interest must rethink this approach, which favors industry over environmental protection.
The writer is a genetic engineering specialist at Greenpeace.
